title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in peer-to-peer training for healthcare providers in literacy promotion, delivering training curriculum in various medical education settings, providing technical assistance for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs, and offering opportunities for local healthcare facilities. The "Prescribe A Book Act" aims to support Pediatric Early Literacy Programs by providing technical assistance to healthcare facilities, offering book discounts, and integrating research into training for healthcare providers. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program involves a 3-part model implemented by trained healthcare providers. The "Prescribe A Book Act" implements a 3-part model where healthcare providers promote early language and literacy by encouraging parents to read aloud to children, providing new books to children aged 6 months to 5 years, and having volunteers offer books in waiting areas. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes early language and literacy by encouraging parents to read aloud to children, providing new books to children aged 6 months to 5 years, and having volunteers offer books in waiting areas. This program demonstrates effectiveness in altering parent behavior regarding reading aloud and improving language skills in young children, supported by research and endorsed by medical associations. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application and provide matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. Grant funds can be used for program implementation. An eligible entity receiving a grant for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies, provide training and technical assistance to contractors, and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. Contractors are selected based on their priority to serve at-risk individuals. Contractors for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs are selected based on serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families, without medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, and migrant children. Children eligible for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs include those from low-income families, without medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited access to libraries. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making payments. Eligible entities receiving grants must report annually on program effectiveness and contractor programs. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is amended to include a new subpart for pediatric early literacy programs, with sections outlining definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, restrictions on payments, and reporting requirements. Eligible entities must have arrangements with book publishers for discounts and report annually on program effectiveness.
